<p><strong>The emerging technology</strong> of <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/quantum-computing-use-cases-are-getting-real-what-you-need-to-know">quantum computing</a> could revolutionize the fight against climate change, transforming the economics of decarbonization and becoming a major factor in limiting global warming to the target temperature of 1.5°C (see sidebar “<a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-quantum-computing">What is quantum computing?</a>”). </p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What is quantum computing?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Quantum computing </strong>is a new technology that leverages the laws of quantum mechanics to produce exponentially higher performance for certain types of calculations, offering the possibility of major breakthroughs across several end markets.</p>
<p>The technology works by calculating with qubits, which can represent 0 and 1 at the same time. By contrast, classical computing calculates with transistors that represent either 0 or 1. In quantum computing, power increases exponentially in proportion to the number of qubits; with classical computing, power increases in a 1:1 relationship to the number of transistors.</p>
<p>While classical computers are better adapted to everyday, simple processing, the new machines are well suited for complex tasks such as quantum simulations in molecular chemistry, optimization, and prime factorization. </p>
<p>Quantum computing would be able to solve these specific problems much faster than even the most powerful supercomputer of today. In addition, the new technology could make it possible to solve certain problems that have long been considered insoluble. As an example, factoring a 2,048-bit prime number with today’s supercomputer takes about one trillion years. With quantum, this calculation could take about one minute.</p>
<p>Recent innovation suggests that the first generation of fault-tolerant quantum computing could be operational by the end of this decade, with some quantum-computing companies suggesting it could be even sooner. </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Even though the technology is in the early stages of development—experts estimate the first generation of fault-tolerant quantum computing<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="010eb0df-13a0-4c10-aabd-11e226a3a723"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="010eb0df-13a0-4c10-aabd-11e226a3a723" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Fault-tolerant quantum computing, in contrast to NISQ, enables sizable quantum computers to use error correction and perform billions more gate operations, which are necessary for most known valuable algorithms. NISQ-era quantum computers have 50 to several hundred qubits, which is not sufficient for error correction, restricting in the number of gate operations. Currently no valuable NISQ algorithms are known.</span></span></span></a></span> will arrive in the second half of this decade—breakthroughs are accelerating, investment dollars are pouring in, and start-ups are proliferating.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="056ae6c2-62ee-45f8-831a-416b6d4b54be"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="056ae6c2-62ee-45f8-831a-416b6d4b54be" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The quantum technology monitor</em>, McKinsey, September 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Major tech companies have already developed small, so-called noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ)  machines, though these aren’t capable of performing the type of calculations that fully capable quantum computers are expected to perform.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Countries and corporates set ambitious new targets for reducing emissions at the 2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP26). Those goals, if fully met, would represent an extraordinary annual investment of $4 trillion by 2030, the largest reallocation of capital in human history. But the measures would only reduce warming to between 1.7°C and 1.8°C by 2050, far short of the 1.5°C level believed necessary to avoid catastrophic, runaway climate change.</p>
<p>Meeting the goal of net-zero emissions that countries and some industries have committed to won’t be possible without huge advances in climate technology that aren’t achievable today. Even the most powerful supercomputers available now are not able to solve some of these problems. Quantum computing could be a game changer in those areas. In all, we think quantum computing could help develop climate technologies able to abate carbon on the order of 7 gigatons a year of additional CO<sub>2</sub> impact by 2035, with the potential to bring the world in line with the 1.5°C target. </p>
<p>Quantum computing could help reduce emissions in some of the most challenging or emissions-intensive areas, such as agriculture or direct-air capture, and could accelerate improvements in technologies required at great scale, such as solar panels or batteries. This article offers a look at some of the breakthroughs the technology could permit and attempts to quantify the impact of leveraging quantum-computer technology that are expected become available this decade.</p>
<h2>Solving so far insoluble problems</h2>
<p>Quantum computing could bring about step changes throughout the economy that would have a huge impact on carbon abatement and carbon removal, including by helping to solve persistent sustainability problems such as curbing methane produced by agriculture, making the production of cement emissions-free, improving electric batteries for vehicles, developing significantly better renewable solar technology, finding a faster way to bring down the cost of hydrogen to make it a viable alternative to fossil fuels, and using green ammonia as a fuel and a fertilizer.</p>
<p>Addressing the five areas designated in the <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take">Climate Math Report</a> as key for decarbonization, we have identified quantum-computing use cases that can pave the way to a net-zero economy. We project that by 2035 the use cases listed below could make it possible to eliminate more than 7 gigatons of CO<sub>2</sub> equivalent (CO<sub>2</sub>e) from the atmosphere a year, compared with the current trajectory, or in aggregate more than 150 gigatons over the next 30 years (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Quantum computing could bring about step changes throughout the economy that would have a huge impact on carbon abatement and carbon removal." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Shift 1: Electrifying our lives</h2>
<h2>
</h2>
<h3>Batteries</h3>
<p>Batteries are a critical element of achieving zero-carbon electrification. They are required to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from transportation and to obtain grid-scale energy storage for intermittent energy sources such as solar cells or wind.</p>
<p>Improving the energy density of lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries enables applications in electric vehicles and energy storage at an affordable cost. Over the past ten years, however, innovation has stalled—battery energy density improved 50 percent between 2011 and 2016, but only 25 percent between 2016 and 2020, and is expected to improve by just 17 percent between 2020 and 2025.</p>
<p>Recent research<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="569a2d3f-3c89-4438-b322-96ae9359a089"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="569a2d3f-3c89-4438-b322-96ae9359a089" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Isaac H. Kim et al., “Fault-tolerant resource estimate for quantum chemical simulations: Case study on Li-ion battery electrolyte molecules,”<em> Physical Review Research</em>, 2022, Volume 4, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> has shown that quantum computing will be able to simulate the chemistry of batteries in ways that can’t be achieved now. Quantum computing could allow breakthroughs by providing a better understanding of electrolyte complex formation, by helping to find a replacement material for cathode/anode with the same properties and/or by eliminating the battery separator. </p>
<p>As a result, we could create batteries with 50 percent higher energy density for use in heavy-goods electric vehicles, which could substantially bring forward their economic use. The carbon benefits to passenger EVs wouldn’t be huge, as these vehicles are expected to reach cost parity in many countries before the first generation of quantum computers is online, but consumers might still enjoy cost savings. </p>
<p>In addition, higher-density energy batteries can serve as a grid-scale storage solution. The impact on the world’s grids could be transformative. Halving the cost of grid-scale storage could enable a step change in the use of solar power, which is becoming economically competitive but is challenged by its generation profile. Our modeling suggests that halving the cost of solar panels could increase their use by 25 percent in Europe by 2050 but halving both solar and batteries might increase solar use by 60 percent (Exhibit 2). Geographies without such a high carbon price will see even greater impacts.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Quantum impacts can be synergistic." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Through the combination of use cases described above, improved batteries could bring about an additional reduction in carbon dioxide emissions of 1.4 gigatons by 2035.</p>
<h2>Shift 2: Adapting industrial operations</h2>
<h3>Cement</h3>
<p>Many parts of the industry produce emissions that are either extremely expensive or logistically challenging to abate.</p>
<p>Cement is a case in point. During calcination in the kiln for the process of making clinker, a powder used to make cement, CO<sub>2</sub> is released from raw materials. This process accounts for approximately two-thirds of cement emissions.</p>
<p>Alternative cement-binding materials (or “clinkers”) can eliminate these emissions, but there’s currently no mature alternative clinker that can significantly reduce emissions at an affordable cost.</p>
<p>There are many possible permutations for such a product, but testing by trial and error is time-consuming and costly. Quantum computing can help to simulate theoretical material combinations to find one that overcomes today’s challenges—durability, availability of raw materials and efflorescence (in the case of alkali-activated binders). This would have an estimated additional impact of 1 gigaton a year by 2035. </p>
<h2>Shift 3: Decarbonizing power and fuel</h2>
<h3>Solar cells</h3>
<p>Solar cells will be one of the key electricity-generation sources in a net-zero economy. But even though they are getting cheaper, they still are far from their theoretical maximum efficiency. </p>
<p>Today’s solar cells rely on crystalline silicon and have an efficiency on the order of 20 percent. Solar cells based on perovskite crystal structures, which have a theoretical efficiency of up to 40 percent, could be a better alternative. They present challenges, however, because they lack long-term stability and could, in some varieties, be more toxic. Furthermore, the technology has not been mass produced yet. </p>
<p>Quantum computing could help tackle these challenges by allowing for precise simulation of perovskite structures in all combinations using different base atoms and doping, thereby identifying higher efficiency, higher durability, and nontoxic solutions. If the theoretical efficiency increase can be reached, the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) would decrease by 50 percent.</p>
<p>By simulating the impact of cheaper and more efficient quantum-enabled solar panels, we see a significant increase in use in areas with lower carbon prices (China, for example). This is also true of countries in Europe with high irradiance (Spain, Greece) or poor conditions for wind energy (Hungary). The impact is magnified when combined with cheap battery storage, as discussed above. </p>
<p>This technology could abate an additional 0.4 gigatons of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions by 2035.</p>
<h3>Hydrogen</h3>
<p>Hydrogen is widely considered to be a viable replacement for fossil fuels in many parts of the economy, especially in industry where high temperature is needed and electrification isn’t possible or sufficient, or where hydrogen is needed as a feedstock, such as steelmaking or ethylene production.   </p>
<p>Before the 2022 gas price spikes, green hydrogen was about 60 percent more expensive than natural gas. But improving electrolysis could significantly decrease the cost of hydrogen. </p>
<p>Polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolyzers split water and are one way to make green hydrogen. They have improved in recent times but still face two major challenges.</p>
<ol>
    <li>They are not as efficient as they could be. We know that “pulsing” the electrical current rather than running it constantly improves efficiency in lab environments, but we don’t understand this enough to get it to work at scale.</li>
    <li>Electrolyzers have delicate membranes that allow the split hydrogen to pass from the anode to the cathode (but keeps the split oxygen out). In addition, they have catalysts that speed up the overall process. Catalysts and membranes do not yet interact well. The more efficient we make the catalyst, the more it wears down the membrane. This doesn’t have to be the case, but we don’t understand the interactions well enough to design better membranes and catalysts.</li>
</ol>
<p>Quantum computing can help model the energy state of pulse electrolysis to optimize catalyst usage, which would increase efficiency.  Quantum computing could also model the chemical composition of catalysts and membranes to ensure the most efficient interactions. And it could push the efficiency of the electrolysis process up to 100 percent and reduce the cost of hydrogen by 35 percent. If combined with cheaper solar cells discovered by quantum computing (discussed above), the cost of hydrogen could be reduced by 60 percent (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex3-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A combination of quantum-computing innovations could put hydrogen’s carbon price on par with that of natural gas by 2030." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex3-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Increased hydrogen use as a result of these improvements could reduce CO<sub>2</sub> emissions by an additional 1.1 gigatons by 2035.</p>
<h3>Ammonia</h3>
<p>Ammonia is best known as a fertilizer, but could also be used as fuel, potentially making it one of the best decarbonization solutions for the world’s ships. Today, it represents 2 percent of total global final energy consumption.</p>
<p>For the moment, ammonia is made through the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process using natural gas. There are several options for creating green ammonia, but they rely on similar processes. For example, green hydrogen can be used as a feedstock, or the carbon dioxide emissions that are caused by the process can be captured and stored.</p>
<p>However, there are other potential approaches, such as nitrogenase bioelectrocatalysis, which is how nitrogen fixation works naturally when plants take nitrogen gas directly from the air and nitrogenase enzymes catalyze its conversion into ammonia. This method is attractive because it can be done at room temperature and at 1 bar pressure, compared with 500°C at high pressure using Haber-Bosch, which consumes large amounts of energy (in the form of natural gas) (Exhibit 4).  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Nitrogen fixation using nitrogenase is a less energy-intensive way of producing ammonia." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Innovation has reached a stage where it might be possible to replicate nitrogen fixation artificially, but only if we can overcome challenges such as enzyme stability, oxygen sensitivity, and low rates of ammonia production by nitrogenase. The concept works in the lab but not at scale.</p>
<p>Quantum computing can help simulate the process of enhancing the stability of the enzyme, protecting it from oxygen and improving the rate of ammonia production by nitrogenase. That would result in a 67 percent cost reduction over today’s green ammonia produced through electrolysis, which would make green ammonia even cheaper than traditionally produced ammonia. Such a cost reduction could not only lessen the CO<sub>2</sub> impacts of the production of ammonia for agricultural use but could also bring forward the breakeven for ammonia in shipping—where it is expected to be a major decarbonization option—forward by ten years.</p>
<p>Using quantum computing to facilitate cheaper green ammonia as a shipping fuel could abate an additional CO<sub>2</sub> by 0.4 gigatons by 2035.</p>
<h2>Shift 4: Ramping up carbon capture and carbon sequestration activity</h2>
<p>Carbon capture is required to achieve net zero. Both types of carbon capture—point source and direct—could be aided by quantum computing.</p>
<h3>Point-source capture</h3>
<p>Point-source carbon capture allows CO<sub>2</sub> to be captured directly from industrial sources such as a cement or steel blast furnace. But the vast majority of CO<sub>2</sub> capture is too expensive to be viable for now, mainly because it is energy intense.</p>
<p>One possible solution: novel solvents, such as water-lean and multiphase solvents, which could offer lower-energy requirements, but it is difficult to predict the properties of the potential material at a molecular level.</p>
<p>Quantum computing promises to enable more accurate modeling of molecular structure to design new, effective solvents for a range of CO<sub>2</sub> sources, which could reduce the cost of the process by 30 to 50 percent. </p>
<p>We believe this has significant potential to decarbonize industrial processes, which could lead to additional decarbonization of up to 1.5 gigatons a year, including cement. If the cement clinker approach described above is successful, this would still have an effect of 0.5 gigatons a year, due to fuel emissions. In addition, alternative clinkers may not be available in some regions.  </p>
<h3>Direct-air capture</h3>
<p>Direct-air capture, which involves sucking CO<sub>2</sub> from the air, is a way to address carbon removals. While the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says this approach is required to achieve net zero, it is very expensive (ranging from $250 to $600 per ton a day today) and even more energy intensive than point-source capture.</p>
<p>Adsorbents are best suited for effective direct-air capture and novel approaches, such as metal organic frameworks, or MOFs, have the potential to greatly reduce the energy requirements and the capital cost of the infrastructure. MOFs act like a giant sponge—as little as a gram can have a surface area larger than a football field—and can absorb and release CO<sub>2</sub> at far lower temperature changes than conventional technology. </p>
<p>Quantum computing can help advance research on novel adsorbents such as MOFs and resolve challenges<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="04c3e357-b41b-4d8c-b477-8588d317ec75"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="04c3e357-b41b-4d8c-b477-8588d317ec75" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Gabriel Greene-Diniz et al., <em>Modelling carbon capture on metal-organic frameworks with quantum computing</em>, March 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> arising from sensitivity to oxidation, water, and degradation caused by CO<sub>2</sub>. </p>
<p>Novel adsorbents that have a higher adsorption rate could reduce the cost of technology to $100 per ton of CO<sub>2</sub>e captured. This could be a critical threshold for uptake, given that corporate climate leaders such as Microsoft<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b1bb84d-a301-45aa-8793-74cd94b880ba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b1bb84d-a301-45aa-8793-74cd94b880ba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jesse Klein, “3 things learned from Microsoft’s carbon removal report,” GreenBiz, April 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> have publicly announced an expectation to pay $100 a ton long term for the highest-quality carbon removals. This would lead to an additional CO<sub>2</sub> reduction of 0.7 gigatons a year by 2035. </p>
<h2>Shift 5: Reforming food and forestry</h2>
<p><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take">Twenty percent of annual greenhouse-gas emissions</a> come from agriculture—and methane emitted by cattle and dairy is the primary contributor (7.9 gigatons of CO<sub>2</sub>e, based on 20-year global-warming potential). </p>
<p>Research has established that low-methane feed additives could effectively stop up to 90 percent of methane emissions. Yet applying those additives for free-range livestock is particularly difficult.</p>
<p>An alternative solution is an antimethane vaccine that produces methanogen-targeting antibodies. This method has had some success in lab conditions, but in a cow’s gut—churning with gastric juices and food—the antibodies struggle to latch on to the right microbes. Quantum computing could accelerate the research to find the right antibodies by precise molecule simulation instead of a costly and long trial-and-error method. With estimated uptake determined according to data from the US Environmental Protection Agency, we arrive at carbon reduction of up to an additional 1 gigaton a year by 2035. </p>
<p>Another prominent use case in agriculture is green ammonia discussed as a fuel above, where today’s Haber-Bosch process uses large amounts of natural gas. Using such an alternative process could have an additional impact of up to 0.25 gigatons a year by 2035, replacing current conventionally produced fertilizers.</p>
<h2>Additional use cases</h2>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Methodology</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>We selected the use cases in this article from a list of more than 150 that present stubborn technical challenges for quantum applicability. We filtered them into two stages: the first for climate impact and the second for the ability of quantum computing to find solutions for the challenges, based on likely stakeholder behavior.</p>
<p>As a result, we have prioritized seven use cases in five areas. Using a conservative estimate, these use cases represent 7 gigatons of additional CO<sub>2</sub> reduction a year in 2035, equivalent to at least 0.2°C of warming avoided by 2050. These estimates only consider use cases we have prioritized so far.</p>
<p>We arrived at our long list through a wide-ranging collection of ideas, expert interviews, reviews of research, and input from industry contacts, including McKinsey’s Technology Council, where we assemble leading quantum technology firms regularly. We approached this process from several angles. For example, we examined both climate technologies that have major cost or implementation barriers as well as theoretical quantum innovations that may have a climatic use. </p>
<p>We then conducted impact analysis on our short list in three steps:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Translate quantum impact to changing stakeholder behavior.</em> We first worked out the new cost of a technology after a quantum leap, using academic reports, expert interviews, or first principles of theoretical limits. Then, to determine stakeholder reactions, we used a “breakeven” logic in simple situations. For example, people switch to a new fuel when it is cheaper. For situations with more complex interactions, we used advanced modeling. One example: solar in grids, where generation/consumption patterns matter.</li>
    <li><em>Investigate the implementation ramp-up for new tech.</em> The delay between the time when a quantum leap is found to improve a technology and the time when a solution can be implemented needs to be factored in. For example, the time for a computer to go live; the time to build additional infrastructure such as solar; and the time to switch out assets such as zero-carbon ships). This interval varies between use cases, with the fastest expected to have impact in 2028 and the slowest starting in 2035.</li>
    <li><em>Subtract carbon impact that would have happened anyway.</em> We create counterfactual scenarios and subtract their benefit. In general, we use a 1.7°C to 1.8°C scenario based on the “stated ambitions” policy from the International Energy Agency after  COP26.</li>
</ol>
<p>For the sake of this work, we assume that the first-working fault-tolerant quantum computer will be deployed in 2026. Though <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/quantum-computing-use-cases-are-getting-real-what-you-need-to-know">consensus expert estimates are closer to 2030</a>, some quantum-computing companies have announced plans to roll them out sooner. It will then take one to two years to discover new technologies. We further assume there will be a ramp-up period ranging from two to seven years, depending on the innovation, to allow technologies to reach full scale because some applications will require large infrastructure (direct-air capture) or will need more time to switch in zero-carbon technologies (ammonia for shipping or vehicles). </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are many more ways that quantum computing could be applied to the fight against climate change. Future possibilities include identification of new thermal-storage materials, high-temperature superconductors as a future base for lower losses in grids, or simulations to support nuclear fusion. Use cases aren’t limited to climate mitigation, but can also apply to adaptation, for example, improvements in weather prediction to give greater warning of major climatic events. But progress on those innovations will have to wait because first-generation machines will not be powerful enough for such breakthroughs (see sidebar “Methodology”). </p>
<h2>Opportunity for corporates</h2>
<p>The leap in CO<sub>2</sub> abatement could be a major opportunity for corporates. With $3 to $5 trillion in value at stake in sustainability, according to <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-economic-transformation-what-would-change-in-the-net-zero-transition">McKinsey research</a>, climate investment is an imperative for big companies. The use cases presented above represent major shifts and potential disruptions in these areas, and they are associated with huge value for players who take the lead. This opportunity is recognized by industry leaders who are already developing capabilities and talent. </p>
<p>Nevertheless, quantum technology is in the early stage and comes with the risks linked to leading-edge technology development, as well as tremendous cost. We have highlighted the stage of the industry in the <a href="/featured-insights/the-rise-of-quantum-computing">Quantum Technology Monitor</a>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="18cccfb2-e30e-4a1f-8c3d-001c398bdd12"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="18cccfb2-e30e-4a1f-8c3d-001c398bdd12" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The quantum technology monitor</em>, McKinsey, September 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The risk to investors can be mitigated somewhat through steps such as onboarding technical experts to run in-depth diligence, forming joint investments with public entities or consortia, and investing in companies that bundle various ventures under one roof and provide the necessary experience to set up and scale these ventures. </p>
<p>In addition, governments have an important role to play by creating programs at universities to develop quantum talent and by providing incentives for quantum innovation for climate, particularly for use cases that today do not have natural corporate partners, such as disaster prediction, or that aren’t economical, such as direct-air capture. Governments could start more research programs like the partnership between IBM and the United Kingdom,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" But even with those measures, the risk and expense remain high (Exhibit 5).  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex5-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Quantum-enabled technologies could put the world back on track to becoming net-zero before 2050." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/quantum%20computing%20just%20might%20save%20the%20planet/svgz-quantumcomputing-ex5-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Here are some questions corporates and investors need to ask before taking a leap into quantum computing.</p>
<ol>
    <li>
    <p>Is quantum computing relevant for you?</p>
    <p>Determine whether there are use cases that can potentially disrupt your industry or your investments and address the decarbonization challenges of your organization. This article has highlighted anecdotal use cases across several categories to showcase the potential impact of quantum computing, but we’ve identified more than 100 sustainability-relevant use cases where quantum computing could play a major role. Quickly identifying use cases that are applicable to you and deciding how to address them can be highly valuable, as talent and capacity will be scarce in this decade.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p>How do I approach quantum computing now, if it is relevant?</p>
    <p>Once you have engaged on quantum computing, building the right kind of approach, mitigating risk and securing access to talent and capacity are key. </p>
    <p>Because of the high cost of this research, corporates can maximize their impact by forming partnerships with other players from their value chains and pooling expense and talent. For example, major consumers of hydrogen might join up with electrolyzer manufacturers to bring down the cost and share the value. These arrangements will require companies to figure out how to share innovation without losing competitive advantage. Collaborations such as joint ventures or precompetitive R&D could be an answer. We also foresee investors willing to support such endeavors to potentially remove some of the risk for corporates. And there are large amounts of dedicated climate finance available, judging by pledges<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="10c2806d-ef27-44e5-9cf3-b6177d1ee33b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="10c2806d-ef27-44e5-9cf3-b6177d1ee33b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Long-term climate finance,” United Nations, accessed May 2, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> made at COP26 that aim to reach the target of $100 billion a year in spending.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p>Do I have to start now?</p>
    <p>While the first fault-tolerant quantum computer is several years away, it is important to start development work now. There is significant prework to be done to get to a maximal return on the significant investment that application of quantum computing will require. </p>
    <p>Determining the exact parameters of a given problem and finding the best possible application will mean collaboration between application experts and quantum-computing technicians well versed in algorithm development. We estimate algorithm development would take up to 18 months, depending on the complexity.</p>
    <p>It will also take time to set up the value chain, production, and go-to-market to ensure they are ready when quantum computing can be deployed and to fully benefit from the value created.</p>
    </li>
</ol>
<p>Quantum computing is a revolutionary technology that could allow for precise molecular-level simulation and a deeper understanding of nature’s basic laws. As this article shows, its development over the next few years could help solve scientific problems that until recently were believed to be insoluble. Clearing away these roadblocks could make the difference between a sustainable future and climate catastrophe.</p>
<p>Making quantum computing a reality will require an exceptional mobilization of resources, expertise, and funds. Only close cooperation between governments, scientists, academics, and investors in developing this technology can make it possible to reach the target for limiting emissions that will keep global warming at 1.5°C and save the planet.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Peter Cooper</strong> is an associate partner in McKinsey’s London office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/dieter-kiewell">Dieter Kiewell</a></strong> is a senior partner; <strong>Philipp Ernst</strong> is a senior expert in the Hamburg office; and <strong>Dickon Pinner</strong> is a senior partner in the Bay Area office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Ivo Langhans, Molly Tinker, and Mateusz Trzaska for their contributions.  </p>

aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Quantum computing just might save the planet","displayName":"Quantum computing just might save the planet","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"f3588a01-bd43-480d-bccd-b3dc4d76c48e","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Quantum computing just might save the planet"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Exponentially more powerful machines could make possible major reductions in emissions, putting the goal of limiting global warming within reach."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-05-19T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe emerging technology\u003c/strong\u003e of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/quantum-computing-use-cases-are-getting-real-what-you-need-to-know\"\u003equantum computing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;could revolutionize the fight against climate change, transforming the economics of decarbonization and becoming a major factor in limiting global warming to the target temperature of 1.5\u0026deg;C (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-explainers/what-is-quantum-computing\"\u003eWhat is quantum computing?\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo;). \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eEven though the technology is in the early stages of development\u0026mdash;experts estimate the first generation of fault-tolerant quantum computing[[Footnote 1]] will arrive in the second half of this decade\u0026mdash;breakthroughs are accelerating, investment dollars are pouring in, and start-ups are proliferating.[[Footnote 2]] Major tech companies have already developed small, so-called noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ)  machines, though these aren\u0026rsquo;t capable of performing the type of calculations that fully capable quantum computers are expected to perform.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eCountries and corporates set ambitious new targets for reducing emissions at the 2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP26). Those goals, if fully met, would represent an extraordinary annual investment of $4 trillion by 2030, the largest reallocation of capital in human history. But the measures would only reduce warming to between 1.7\u0026deg;C and 1.8\u0026deg;C by 2050, far short of the 1.5\u0026deg;C level believed necessary to avoid catastrophic, runaway climate change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeeting the goal of net-zero emissions that countries and some industries have committed to won\u0026rsquo;t be possible without huge advances in climate technology that aren\u0026rsquo;t achievable today. Even the most powerful supercomputers available now are not able to solve some of these problems. Quantum computing could be a game changer in those areas. In all, we think quantum computing could help develop climate technologies able to abate carbon on the order of 7 gigatons a year of additional CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e impact by 2035, with the potential to bring the world in line with the 1.5\u0026deg;C target. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing could help reduce emissions in some of the most challenging or emissions-intensive areas, such as agriculture or direct-air capture, and could accelerate improvements in technologies required at great scale, such as solar panels or batteries. This article offers a look at some of the breakthroughs the technology could permit and attempts to quantify the impact of leveraging quantum-computer technology that are expected become available this decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSolving so far insoluble problems\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing could bring about step changes throughout the economy that would have a huge impact on carbon abatement and carbon removal, including by helping to solve persistent sustainability problems such as curbing methane produced by agriculture, making the production of cement emissions-free, improving electric batteries for vehicles, developing significantly better renewable solar technology, finding a faster way to bring down the cost of hydrogen to make it a viable alternative to fossil fuels, and using green ammonia as a fuel and a fertilizer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAddressing the five areas designated in the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take\"\u003eClimate Math Report\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as key for decarbonization, we have identified quantum-computing use cases that can pave the way to a net-zero economy. We project that by 2035 the use cases listed below could make it possible to eliminate more than 7 gigatons of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e equivalent (CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee) from the atmosphere a year, compared with the current trajectory, or in aggregate more than 150 gigatons over the next 30 years (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eShift 1: Electrifying our lives\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\n\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBatteries\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBatteries are a critical element of achieving zero-carbon electrification. They are required to reduce CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions from transportation and to obtain grid-scale energy storage for intermittent energy sources such as solar cells or wind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImproving the energy density of lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries enables applications in electric vehicles and energy storage at an affordable cost. Over the past ten years, however, innovation has stalled\u0026mdash;battery energy density improved 50 percent between 2011 and 2016, but only 25 percent between 2016 and 2020, and is expected to improve by just 17 percent between 2020 and 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecent research[[Footnote 3]] has shown that quantum computing will be able to simulate the chemistry of batteries in ways that can\u0026rsquo;t be achieved now. Quantum computing could allow breakthroughs by providing a better understanding of electrolyte complex formation, by helping to find a replacement material for cathode/anode with the same properties and/or by eliminating the battery separator. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result, we could create batteries with 50 percent higher energy density for use in heavy-goods electric vehicles, which could substantially bring forward their economic use. The carbon benefits to passenger EVs wouldn\u0026rsquo;t be huge, as these vehicles are expected to reach cost parity in many countries before the first generation of quantum computers is online, but consumers might still enjoy cost savings. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, higher-density energy batteries can serve as a grid-scale storage solution. The impact on the world\u0026rsquo;s grids could be transformative. Halving the cost of grid-scale storage could enable a step change in the use of solar power, which is becoming economically competitive but is challenged by its generation profile. Our modeling suggests that halving the cost of solar panels could increase their use by 25 percent in Europe by 2050 but halving both solar and batteries might increase solar use by 60 percent (Exhibit 2). Geographies without such a high carbon price will see even greater impacts.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThrough the combination of use cases described above, improved batteries could bring about an additional reduction in carbon dioxide emissions of 1.4 gigatons by 2035.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShift 2: Adapting industrial operations\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCement\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany parts of the industry produce emissions that are either extremely expensive or logistically challenging to abate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCement is a case in point. During calcination in the kiln for the process of making clinker, a powder used to make cement, CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e is released from raw materials. This process accounts for approximately two-thirds of cement emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlternative cement-binding materials (or \u0026ldquo;clinkers\u0026rdquo;) can eliminate these emissions, but there\u0026rsquo;s currently no mature alternative clinker that can significantly reduce emissions at an affordable cost.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are many possible permutations for such a product, but testing by trial and error is time-consuming and costly. Quantum computing can help to simulate theoretical material combinations to find one that overcomes today\u0026rsquo;s challenges\u0026mdash;durability, availability of raw materials and efflorescence (in the case of alkali-activated binders). This would have an estimated additional impact of 1 gigaton a year by 2035. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShift 3: Decarbonizing power and fuel\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSolar cells\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolar cells will be one of the key electricity-generation sources in a net-zero economy. But even though they are getting cheaper, they still are far from their theoretical maximum efficiency. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eToday\u0026rsquo;s solar cells rely on crystalline silicon and have an efficiency on the order of 20 percent. Solar cells based on perovskite crystal structures, which have a theoretical efficiency of up to 40 percent, could be a better alternative. They present challenges, however, because they lack long-term stability and could, in some varieties, be more toxic. Furthermore, the technology has not been mass produced yet. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing could help tackle these challenges by allowing for precise simulation of perovskite structures in all combinations using different base atoms and doping, thereby identifying higher efficiency, higher durability, and nontoxic solutions. If the theoretical efficiency increase can be reached, the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) would decrease by 50 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy simulating the impact of cheaper and more efficient quantum-enabled solar panels, we see a significant increase in use in areas with lower carbon prices (China, for example). This is also true of countries in Europe with high irradiance (Spain, Greece) or poor conditions for wind energy (Hungary). The impact is magnified when combined with cheap battery storage, as discussed above. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis technology could abate an additional 0.4 gigatons of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions by 2035.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHydrogen\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHydrogen is widely considered to be a viable replacement for fossil fuels in many parts of the economy, especially in industry where high temperature is needed and electrification isn\u0026rsquo;t possible or sufficient, or where hydrogen is needed as a feedstock, such as steelmaking or ethylene production.   \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore the 2022 gas price spikes, green hydrogen was about 60 percent more expensive than natural gas. But improving electrolysis could significantly decrease the cost of hydrogen. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePolymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolyzers split water and are one way to make green hydrogen. They have improved in recent times but still face two major challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThey are not as efficient as they could be. We know that \u0026ldquo;pulsing\u0026rdquo; the electrical current rather than running it constantly improves efficiency in lab environments, but we don\u0026rsquo;t understand this enough to get it to work at scale.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eElectrolyzers have delicate membranes that allow the split hydrogen to pass from the anode to the cathode (but keeps the split oxygen out). In addition, they have catalysts that speed up the overall process. Catalysts and membranes do not yet interact well. The more efficient we make the catalyst, the more it wears down the membrane. This doesn\u0026rsquo;t have to be the case, but we don\u0026rsquo;t understand the interactions well enough to design better membranes and catalysts.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing can help model the energy state of pulse electrolysis to optimize catalyst usage, which would increase efficiency.  Quantum computing could also model the chemical composition of catalysts and membranes to ensure the most efficient interactions. And it could push the efficiency of the electrolysis process up to 100 percent and reduce the cost of hydrogen by 35 percent. If combined with cheaper solar cells discovered by quantum computing (discussed above), the cost of hydrogen could be reduced by 60 percent (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eIncreased hydrogen use as a result of these improvements could reduce CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions by an additional 1.1 gigatons by 2035.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAmmonia\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmmonia is best known as a fertilizer, but could also be used as fuel, potentially making it one of the best decarbonization solutions for the world\u0026rsquo;s ships. Today, it represents 2 percent of total global final energy consumption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the moment, ammonia is made through the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process using natural gas. There are several options for creating green ammonia, but they rely on similar processes. For example, green hydrogen can be used as a feedstock, or the carbon dioxide emissions that are caused by the process can be captured and stored.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, there are other potential approaches, such as nitrogenase bioelectrocatalysis, which is how nitrogen fixation works naturally when plants take nitrogen gas directly from the air and nitrogenase enzymes catalyze its conversion into ammonia. This method is attractive because it can be done at room temperature and at 1 bar pressure, compared with 500\u0026deg;C at high pressure using Haber-Bosch, which consumes large amounts of energy (in the form of natural gas) (Exhibit 4).  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eInnovation has reached a stage where it might be possible to replicate nitrogen fixation artificially, but only if we can overcome challenges such as enzyme stability, oxygen sensitivity, and low rates of ammonia production by nitrogenase. The concept works in the lab but not at scale.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing can help simulate the process of enhancing the stability of the enzyme, protecting it from oxygen and improving the rate of ammonia production by nitrogenase. That would result in a 67 percent cost reduction over today\u0026rsquo;s green ammonia produced through electrolysis, which would make green ammonia even cheaper than traditionally produced ammonia. Such a cost reduction could not only lessen the CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e impacts of the production of ammonia for agricultural use but could also bring forward the breakeven for ammonia in shipping\u0026mdash;where it is expected to be a major decarbonization option\u0026mdash;forward by ten years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing quantum computing to facilitate cheaper green ammonia as a shipping fuel could abate an additional CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e by 0.4 gigatons by 2035.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShift 4: Ramping up carbon capture and carbon sequestration activity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCarbon capture is required to achieve net zero. Both types of carbon capture\u0026mdash;point source and direct\u0026mdash;could be aided by quantum computing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePoint-source capture\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePoint-source carbon capture allows CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e to be captured directly from industrial sources such as a cement or steel blast furnace. But the vast majority of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e capture is too expensive to be viable for now, mainly because it is energy intense.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne possible solution: novel solvents, such as water-lean and multiphase solvents, which could offer lower-energy requirements, but it is difficult to predict the properties of the potential material at a molecular level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing promises to enable more accurate modeling of molecular structure to design new, effective solvents for a range of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e sources, which could reduce the cost of the process by 30 to 50 percent. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe this has significant potential to decarbonize industrial processes, which could lead to additional decarbonization of up to 1.5 gigatons a year, including cement. If the cement clinker approach described above is successful, this would still have an effect of 0.5 gigatons a year, due to fuel emissions. In addition, alternative clinkers may not be available in some regions.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDirect-air capture\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDirect-air capture, which involves sucking CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e from the air, is a way to address carbon removals. While the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says this approach is required to achieve net zero, it is very expensive (ranging from $250 to $600 per ton a day today) and even more energy intensive than point-source capture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdsorbents are best suited for effective direct-air capture and novel approaches, such as metal organic frameworks, or MOFs, have the potential to greatly reduce the energy requirements and the capital cost of the infrastructure. MOFs act like a giant sponge\u0026mdash;as little as a gram can have a surface area larger than a football field\u0026mdash;and can absorb and release CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e at far lower temperature changes than conventional technology. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing can help advance research on novel adsorbents such as MOFs and resolve challenges[[Footnote 4]] arising from sensitivity to oxidation, water, and degradation caused by CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNovel adsorbents that have a higher adsorption rate could reduce the cost of technology to $100 per ton of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee captured. This could be a critical threshold for uptake, given that corporate climate leaders such as Microsoft[[Footnote 5]] have publicly announced an expectation to pay $100 a ton long term for the highest-quality carbon removals. This would lead to an additional CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e\u0026nbsp;reduction of 0.7 gigatons a year by 2035. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShift 5: Reforming food and forestry\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take\"\u003eTwenty percent of annual greenhouse-gas emissions\u003c/a\u003e come from agriculture\u0026mdash;and methane emitted by cattle and dairy is the primary contributor (7.9 gigatons of CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee, based on 20-year global-warming potential). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResearch has established that low-methane feed additives could effectively stop up to 90 percent of methane emissions. Yet applying those additives for free-range livestock is particularly difficult.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn alternative solution is an antimethane vaccine that produces methanogen-targeting antibodies. This method has had some success in lab conditions, but in a cow\u0026rsquo;s gut\u0026mdash;churning with gastric juices and food\u0026mdash;the antibodies struggle to latch on to the right microbes. Quantum computing could accelerate the research to find the right antibodies by precise molecule simulation instead of a costly and long trial-and-error method. With estimated uptake determined according to data from the US Environmental Protection Agency, we arrive at carbon reduction of up to an additional 1 gigaton a year by 2035. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother prominent use case in agriculture is green ammonia discussed as a fuel above, where today\u0026rsquo;s Haber-Bosch process uses large amounts of natural gas. Using such an alternative process could have an additional impact of up to 0.25 gigatons a year by 2035, replacing current conventionally produced fertilizers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAdditional use cases\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThere are many more ways that quantum computing could be applied to the fight against climate change. Future possibilities include identification of new thermal-storage materials, high-temperature superconductors as a future base for lower losses in grids, or simulations to support nuclear fusion. Use cases aren\u0026rsquo;t limited to climate mitigation, but can also apply to adaptation, for example, improvements in weather prediction to give greater warning of major climatic events. But progress on those innovations will have to wait because first-generation machines will not be powerful enough for such breakthroughs (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Methodology\u0026rdquo;). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOpportunity for corporates\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe leap in CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e abatement could be a major opportunity for corporates. With $3 to $5 trillion in value at stake in sustainability, according to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-economic-transformation-what-would-change-in-the-net-zero-transition\"\u003eMcKinsey research\u003c/a\u003e, climate investment is an imperative for big companies. The use cases presented above represent major shifts and potential disruptions in these areas, and they are associated with huge value for players who take the lead. This opportunity is recognized by industry leaders who are already developing capabilities and talent. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNevertheless, quantum technology is in the early stage and comes with the risks linked to leading-edge technology development, as well as tremendous cost. We have highlighted\u0026nbsp;the stage of the industry in the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-rise-of-quantum-computing\"\u003eQuantum Technology Monitor\u003c/a\u003e.[[Footnote 6]] The risk to investors can be mitigated somewhat through steps such as onboarding technical experts to run in-depth diligence, forming joint investments with public entities or consortia, and investing in companies that bundle various ventures under one roof and provide the necessary experience to set up and scale these ventures. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, governments have an important role to play by creating programs at universities to develop quantum talent and by providing incentives for quantum innovation for climate, particularly for use cases that today do not have natural corporate partners, such as disaster prediction, or that aren\u0026rsquo;t economical, such as direct-air capture. Governments could start more research programs like the partnership between IBM and the United Kingdom,[[Footnote 7]] the collaboration between IBM and Fraunhofer-Gesellschaft,[[Footnote 8]] the public\u0026ndash;private partnership Quantum Delta[[Footnote 9]] in the Netherlands, and the collaboration between the United States and the United Kingdom.[[Footnote 10]] By tapping into quantum computing for sustainability, countries will accelerate the green transition, achieve national commitments, and get a head start in export markets. But even with those measures, the risk and expense remain high (Exhibit 5).  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some questions corporates and investors need to ask before taking a leap into quantum computing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eIs quantum computing relevant for you?\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eDetermine whether there are use cases that can potentially disrupt your industry or your investments and address the decarbonization challenges of your organization. This article has highlighted anecdotal use cases across several categories to showcase the potential impact of quantum computing, but we\u0026rsquo;ve identified more than 100 sustainability-relevant use cases where quantum computing could play a major role. Quickly identifying use cases that are applicable to you and deciding how to address them can be highly valuable, as talent and capacity will be scarce in this decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eHow do I approach quantum computing now, if it is relevant?\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eOnce you have engaged on quantum computing, building the right kind of approach, mitigating risk and securing access to talent and capacity are key. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eBecause of the high cost of this research, corporates can maximize their impact by forming partnerships with other players from their value chains and pooling expense and talent. For example, major consumers of hydrogen might join up with electrolyzer manufacturers to bring down the cost and share the value. These arrangements will require companies to figure out how to share innovation without losing competitive advantage. Collaborations such as joint ventures or precompetitive R\u0026amp;D could be an answer. We also foresee investors willing to support such endeavors to potentially remove some of the risk for corporates. And there are large amounts of dedicated climate finance available, judging by pledges[[Footnote 11]] made at COP26 that aim to reach the target of $100 billion a year in spending.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eDo I have to start now?\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eWhile the first fault-tolerant quantum computer is several years away, it is important to start development work now. There is significant prework to be done to get to a maximal return on the significant investment that application of quantum computing will require. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eDetermining the exact parameters of a given problem and finding the best possible application will mean collaboration between application experts and quantum-computing technicians well versed in algorithm development. We estimate algorithm development would take up to 18 months, depending on the complexity.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eIt will also take time to set up the value chain, production, and go-to-market to ensure they are ready when quantum computing can be deployed and to fully benefit from the value created.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing is a revolutionary technology that could allow for precise molecular-level simulation and a deeper understanding of nature\u0026rsquo;s basic laws. As this article shows, its development over the next few years could help solve scientific problems that until recently were believed to be insoluble. Clearing away these roadblocks could make the difference between a sustainable future and climate catastrophe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMaking quantum computing a reality will require an exceptional mobilization of resources, expertise, and funds. Only close cooperation between governments, scientists, academics, and investors in developing this technology can make it possible to reach the target for limiting emissions that will keep global warming at 1.5\u0026deg;C and save the planet.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-05-19T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFault-tolerant quantum computing, in contrast to NISQ, enables sizable quantum computers to use error correction and perform billions more gate operations, which are necessary for most known valuable algorithms. current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuantum computing \u003c/strong\u003eis a new technology that leverages the laws of quantum mechanics to produce exponentially higher performance for certain types of calculations, offering the possibility of major breakthroughs across several end markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe technology works by calculating with qubits, which can represent 0 and 1 at the same time. By contrast, classical computing calculates with transistors that represent either 0 or 1. In quantum computing, power increases exponentially in proportion to the number of qubits; with classical computing, power increases in a 1:1 relationship to the number of transistors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile classical computers are better adapted to everyday, simple processing, the new machines are well suited for complex tasks such as quantum simulations in molecular chemistry, optimization, and prime factorization. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuantum computing would be able to solve these specific problems much faster than even the most powerful supercomputer of today. In addition, the new technology could make it possible to solve certain problems that have long been considered insoluble. As an example, factoring a 2,048-bit prime number with today\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;supercomputer takes about one trillion years. With quantum, this calculation could take about one minute.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecent innovation suggests that the first generation of fault-tolerant quantum computing could be operational by the end of this decade, with some quantum-computing companies suggesting it could be even sooner. \u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What is quantum computing?"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eWe selected the use cases in this article from a list of more than 150 that present stubborn technical challenges for quantum applicability. We filtered them into two stages: the first for climate impact and the second for the ability of quantum computing to find solutions for the challenges, based on likely stakeholder behavior.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result, we have prioritized seven use cases in five areas. Using a conservative estimate, these use cases represent 7 gigatons of additional CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e reduction a year in 2035, equivalent to at least 0.2\u0026deg;C of warming avoided by 2050. These estimates only consider use cases we have prioritized so far.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe arrived at our long list through a wide-ranging collection of ideas, expert interviews, reviews of research, and input from industry contacts, including McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Technology Council, where we assemble leading quantum technology firms regularly. We approached this process from several angles. For example, we examined both climate technologies that have major cost or implementation barriers as well as theoretical quantum innovations that may have a climatic use. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe then conducted impact analysis on our short list in three steps:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTranslate quantum impact to changing stakeholder behavior.\u003c/em\u003e We first worked out the new cost of a technology after a quantum leap, using academic reports, expert interviews, or first principles of theoretical limits. Then, to determine stakeholder reactions, we used a \u0026ldquo;breakeven\u0026rdquo; logic in simple situations. For example, people switch to a new fuel when it is cheaper. For situations with more complex interactions, we used advanced modeling. One example: solar in grids, where generation/consumption patterns matter.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvestigate the implementation ramp-up for new tech.\u003c/em\u003e The delay between the time when a quantum leap is found to improve a technology and the time when a solution can be implemented needs to be factored in. For example, the time for a computer to go live; the time to build additional infrastructure such as solar; and the time to switch out assets such as zero-carbon ships). This interval varies between use cases, with the fastest expected to have impact in 2028 and the slowest starting in 2035.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSubtract carbon impact that would have happened anyway.\u003c/em\u003e We create counterfactual scenarios and subtract their benefit. In general, we use a 1.7\u0026deg;C to 1.8\u0026deg;C scenario based on the \u0026ldquo;stated ambitions\u0026rdquo; policy from the International Energy Agency after  COP26.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the sake of this work, we assume that the first-working fault-tolerant quantum computer will be deployed in 2026. Though \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/quantum-computing-use-cases-are-getting-real-what-you-need-to-know\"\u003econsensus expert estimates are closer to 2030\u003c/a\u003e, some quantum-computing companies have announced plans to roll them out sooner. It will then take one to two years to discover new technologies. We further assume there will be a ramp-up period ranging from two to seven years, depending on the innovation, to allow technologies to reach full scale because some applications will require large infrastructure (direct-air capture) or will need more time to switch in zero-carbon technologies (ammonia for shipping or vehicles).
